questions.question_text: A lower limit of a Control Area shall be established at a height above the ground level or water of not less than:
options: 150 metres
200 metres
300 metres

questions.question_text: The Approach Control Service is an air traffic control service
options: provided for the arriving and departing controlled flights
for IFR flights arriving and departing
provided for IFR traffic within a Control Zone

questions.question_text: The units providing Air Traffic Services are:
options: Area control Center- Advisory Center- Flight information Center- Approach Control Office and Tower
Area Control Center- Flight Information Center- Approach Cotrol Office- Aerodrome Control Tower and Air Traffic Services reporting office
Area Control Center- Approach Control Office and Aerodrome Control Tower only.

questions.question_text: Air traffic control service is provided for the purpose of:
options: Avoiding collisions between all aircraft and maintaining an orderly flow of air traffic
Preventing collisions between aircraft, between aircraft and obstacles on the manoeuvring area and expediting and maintaining an orderly flow of air traffic
Preventing collisions between controlled air traffic and expediting and maintaining an orderly flow of air traffic

questions.question_text: To perform a VFR flight in airspace classification E a clearance and/or two-way radio communication is required
options: a clearance is required
two-way radio communication is not required

questions.question_text: Which statement is correct?
options: The lower limit of an UIR may coincide with an IFR cruising level
The lower limit of a TMA shall be established at a height of at least 700ft AGL
The upper limit of a CTR shall be established at a height of at least 3000ft AMSL

questions.question_text: What is the speed limit (IAS) in an airspace class E?
options: 250kt VFR and IFR, all levels
250kt for IFR and VFR up to FL 100
250 kt only for IFR up to FL 100

questions.question_text: The speed limitation for IFR flights inside ATS airspace classified as C, when flying below 3050m (1000ft) AMSL, is:
options: 250kt IAS
Not applicable
250kt TAS

questions.question_text: RCP 10 means:
options: 10 is the number of seconds it takes for an instruction to travel from the ground to aircraft and acknowledgment back to the ground.
10 is the maximum number of minutes it takes for an instruction to be executed by an aircraft.
Aircraft must communicate with ATC every 10 minutes.

questions.question_text: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all flights are subject to air traffic control service and are separated from each other is classified as
options: Airspace C
Airspace B
Airspace D

questions.question_text: The speed limitation for both IFR flights and VFR flights inside ATS airspace classified as B, when flying below 3050m (10000ft) AMLS, is:
options: 260kt IAS
Not applicable
250kt IAS

questions.question_text: Air traffic services unit clocks and other time recording devices shall be checked as necessary to ensure correct time within plus or minus
options: 1 minute of UTC at all times
15 seconds of UTC at all times
30 seconds of UTC at all times

questions.question_text: The following airspace falls under Kolkata FIR?
options: VED
VEB
VOR

questions.question_text: The VMC minima for a VFR flight inside an ATS airspace classified as B, is:
options: 8km visibility when at or above 3050m (10000ft) AMSL and clear of clouds
8km visibility when at or above 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, and 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from clouds
5NM visibility when below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from cloud

questions.question_text: A VFR flight when flying inside an ATS airspace classified as B has to maintain the following minima of flight visibility and distance from clouds
options: 5km visibility, 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from clouds
8km below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, 1500m horizontal and 300m vertical from clouds
5km below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL and clear of clouds

questions.question_text: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all flights are subject to air traffic control service and IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and from VFR flights VFR flights are separated from IFR flights and receive traffic information in respect of other VFR flights, is classified as:
options: Airspace B
Airspace E
Airspace C

questions.question_text: Which condition is requested so that an aerodrome may be considered controlled?
options: The aerodrome shall be located within a Control Zone (CTR) and provided with a Control Tower
The aerodrome shall be provided with a Control Tower
The aerodrome shall be located within a Control Zone

questions.question_text: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted and all flights are subject to air traffic control service. IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and receive traffic information in respect of VFR flights. VFR flights receive traffic information in respect of all other flights, is classified as:
options: Airspace B
Airspace D
Airspace A

questions.question_text: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted are subject to Air Traffic Control Service and are separated from other IFR flights. All flights receive traffic information as far as practical, is classified as
options: Airspace D
Airspace A
Airspace E

questions.question_text: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all participating IFR flights receive an air traffic advisory service and all flights receive flight information service if requested, is classified
options: Airspace F
Airspace E
Airspace D

questions.question_text: Which statement regarding approach control service is correct?
options: Approach control have to advise the aircraft operators about substantial delays in departure in any event when they are expected to exceed 45 minutes
During a visual approach an aircraft is maintaining its own separation
If it is anticipated that an aircraft has to hold for 30 minutes or more, an Expected Approach Time will be transmitted by the most expeditious means to the aircraft

questions.question_text: Which statement regarding aerodrome control service is correct?
options: An aircraft entering the traffic circuit without permission of ATC, will be cleared to land if this is desirable
Suspension of VFR operations can not be initiated by the aerodrome controller
ATC permission is required for entering the apron with a vehicle

questions.question_text: In ATS route designator UA1Y what does U mean:
options: Upper.
Undirectional.
Uniform.

questions.question_text: Special VFR flights may be authorized to operate locally within a control zone when the ground visibility is not less than 1500 metres, even when the aircraft Is not equipped with a functioning radio receiver within class:
options: D airspace
D and E airspace
E airspace

questions.question_text: Flight information service shall be provided to all aircraft which are likely to be affected by the information and which are:
options: Provided with the air traffic control services and otherwise known to the relevant air traffic service units
Known to the relevant air traffic services units by a filed flightplan
Provided with air traffic control services, only

questions.question_text: Alerting service shall be provided:
options: For all controlled flight, to any aircraft known or believed to be subject of unlawful interference, and in so far as practicable to all aircraft having filed a flight plan or otherwise known to the ATS
For all aircraft provided with air traffic control services, only
To any aircraft known or believed to be subject of unlawful interference, only

questions.question_text: The speed limitation for IFR flights inside ATS airspace classified as E, when flying below 3050m (10000ft) AMSL, is:
options: 250kt TAS
250kt IAS
Not applicable

questions.question_text: Air Traffic Service unit means:
options: Air Traffic Control units and Air Services reporting offices
Flight Information Centers and Air Services reporting offices
Air Traffic Control units, Flight Information Centers or Air Services reporting offices

questions.question_text: A controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth Is:
options: Advisory airspace
Control area
Flight Information Region

questions.question_text: Tirupati aerodrome designator is?
options: VATP
VOTP
VITP

questions.question_text: Aerodrome traffic is:
options: All traffic on the manoeuvring area and flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome
All traffic in the aerodrome circuit
All traffic on the manoeuvring area

questions.question_text: Which of the following Annexes to the Chicago convention contains international standards and recommended practices for air traffic services (ATS)?
options: Annex 6
Annex 14
Annex 11

questions.question_text: An information issued by a meteorological watch office concerning the occurence or expected occurence of specified en-route weather phenomena which may affect the safety of low-level aircraft operations and which was not already included in the forecast issued for low level flights in the flight information region concerned or sub-area thereof is
options: An En-Route Met Report
A NOTAM
An AIRMET information

questions.question_text: Regarding Aerodrome Flight Information (AFIS):
options: Its purpose is to supply ATC services but it is not a state organisation
It can only supply limited services to the users and under no circumstances may it supply ATC services
It has the same privileges and prerogatives as an ATC organisation but its activity is neither continuous nor regular

questions.question_text: Air Traffic Control service shall be provided to::
options: All IFR flights in class A, B, C, D, E and F airspaces.
All VFR flights in class B, C, D and E airspaces.
To all aerodrome traffic at controlled aerodromes.

questions.question_text: Flight Information Region (FIR) is an airspace within which the following services are provided:
options: Flight Information Service and Alerting Service
Flight Information Service and Advisory Service
Flight Information Service, Alerting Service and Advisory Service

questions.question_text: Control Area (CTA) is defined as follows:
options: A controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth
A controlled airspace extending upwards from the surface of the earth to a specified limit
A controlled airspace extending upwards from a height of 900ft above the earth

questions.question_text: Aerodrome local flying area is to be considered, if ATZ is not notified:
options: With in 5 NM of ARP up to 3000 feet.
With in 25 NM of ARP up to 10,000 feet.
With in 10 NM of ARP up to 5000 feet.

questions.question_text: An air traffic control unit:
options: May ask an aircraft to temporarily change its callsign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confusion between two or more similar callsigns
May not ask an aircraft to change its callsign after accepting the flight plan
Must not ask an aircraft to change its callsign

questions.question_text: Required Navigation Performance (RNP) shall be prescribed
options: By regional air navigation agreements
By states but not on the basis of regional air agreements
By states on the basis of regional air navigation agreements

questions.question_text: A Control Zone shall extend laterally to at least:
options: 10 miles from the centre of the aerodrome or aerodromes concerned in the direction from which approaches may be made
5 nautical miles from the centre of the aerodrome or aerodromes concerned in the direction from which approaches may be made
20 miles from the centre of the aerodrome or aerodromes concerned in the direction from which approaches may be made

questions.question_text: G245ZF is a designator for:
options: a SID
a STAR
an ATS Route

questions.question_text: An ATS airspace where IFR and VFR are permitted and receive flight information service if requested, is classified as
options: Airspace G
Airspace E
Airspace C

questions.question_text: Concerning to RNP (Required Navigation Performance) types, the indication RNP 4, represents a navigation accuracy of
options: Plus or minus 4 NM on a 95% containment basis
Plus or minus 4 NM on a 98% containment basis
Plus or minus 4 NM on a 90% containment basis

questions.question_text: Area Control Centers Issue clearances for the purpose of:
options: Achieving separation between IFR flights
Achieving separation between controlled flights
Providing flight information Service

questions.question_text: Clearances will be issued by an ATC unit for the purpose of:
options: Achieving separation between controlled flights
Providing alerting services
Providing advisory services

questions.question_text: You receive an IFR enroute clearance starting: Clearance expires at 0920. What does it mean?
options: If not airborne until 0920, a new clearance has to be issued
The take off clearance is expected at 0920
After 0920 return to the ramp and file a new flight plan

questions.question_text: ATIS broadcast
options: Shall only be transmitted on a discrete VHF frequency
Shall not be transmitted on the voice channel of an ILS
Shall not be transmitted on the voice of VOR

questions.question_text: Whenever ATIS is provided, the preparation and dissemination of the ATIS message shall be the responsibility of
options: Both air traffic services and the meteorological office
The meteorological office serving the aerodromes
The air traffic services

questions.question_text: Whenever ATIS is provided, the broadcast information shall be updated
options: As prescribed by the meteorological office
Immediately a significant change occurs
As prescribed by the state

questions.question_text: The ATIS broadcast message should, whenever practicable, not exceed
options: 30 seconds
1 minute
2 minutes

questions.question_text: ATIS broadcast messages containing departure and arrival information should include cloud cover, when the clouds are:
options: Below 900m (3000ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater
Below 2000m (600ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater
Below 1500m (5000ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater

questions.question_text: When are ATIS broadcasts updated?
options: Upon receipt of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values
Every 30 minutes if weather conditions are below those for VFR; otherwise hourly
Only when the ceiling and/or visibility changes by a reportable value

questions.question_text: Flight Information Service shall be provided to aircraft in order to avoid collision hazards when operating in airspace classes:
options: F and G only
C, D, E, F and G
A, B, C, D, E, F and G

questions.question_text: The lateral limit of CTR shall extend to atleast NMs from the center of aerodrome in directions from where approaches may be made:
At radio communications, "Distress" differs from "Urgency" because in the first case
options: The aeroplane has suffered damages which impair its fitness to fly
There is a serious and imminent danger requiring immediate assistance
The aeroplane will not be able to reach a suitable aerodrome

questions.question_text: The Alerting Service is provided by:
options: The Area Control Centers
The ATS unit responsible for the aircraft at that moment
Only by ATC units

questions.question_text: The phases related to an aircraft in emergency or believed in emergency are:
options: Uncertainty phase, distress phase, urgency phase
Uncertainty phase, alert phase, distress phase
Uncertainty phase, urgency phase, distress phase

questions.question_text: When an aircraft is experiencing difficulties, triggering of the alert phase is the responsibility of
options: Search and rescue coordination centers
Control centers only
Air traffic control and flight information centers

questions.question_text: What type of flight is allowed in class A airspace
options: IFR only
IFR and VFR
IFR and special VFR

questions.question_text: Alert phase is defined as follows:
options: A situation where an apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants
An emergency event in which an aircraft and its occupants are considered to be threatened by a danger
A situation related to an aircraft and its occupants are considered to be in a state of emergency

questions.question_text: A situation in which apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft. To which emergency phase does this situation correspond?
options: ALERFA
INCERFA
DETRESFA

questions.question_text: Which of the following signals is a distress signal?
options: In radiotelephony the spoken words PAN, PAN
A parachute flare showing a red light
The repeated switching on and off of the navigation lights

questions.question_text: An aircraft is in emergency when:
options: It is threatened by grave danger
It is threatened by grave danger and requires immediate assistance
It is forced to land

questions.question_text: The different emergency phases (in correct order) are:
options: INCERFA, ALERTFA and DISTRESFA
INCERFA, ALERFA, DETRESFA
ALERTFA, DISTRESFA, RESCUEFA

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements describes the Alert Phase (ALERFA)?
options: An aircraft fails to arrive within 30 minutes of the ETA which was last notified to ATC.
An aircraft declares that the fuel remaining is insufficient to reach safety.
An aircraft which has been cleared to land fails to land within 5 minutes of the ETA and communication has not been re-established.

questions.question_text: DETRESFA is where:
options: An aircraft fails to land within 5 minutes of being cleared to land
All answers are correct.
The fuel on board is considered to be exhausted

questions.question_text: RSP 180 indicates:
options: Time in seconds taken by a pilot to receive surveillance instructions from the controller.
Time in seconds between flight crew/HMI and controller/HMI.
Distance in NMs between two way points in defined RSP airspace.

questions.question_text: A strayed aircraft is an aircraft:
options: that has deviated significantly from its intended track or reports that it is lost.
that has been observed or is reported to be operating in a given area but whose identity has not been established.
only that aircraft which has deviated significantly its intended track.

questions.question_text: Having filed a flight plan to a particular destination and having landed at another destination, you should notify ATC:
options: within 60 minutes after landing at the alternate destination
within 30 minutes after landing at the alternate destination
within 30 minutes of your intended ETA at your original destination.

questions.question_text: Designated airspace within controlled airspace in India is classified as Class:
options: C
D
C and D.

questions.question_text: TSA801(A) Is an airspace:
options: temporarily segregated and allocated in Delhi FIR
temporarily segregated and allocated in Chennai FIR
denoting an area navigation route in India

questions.question_text: Temporary Reserved Area (TRA) is an airspace temporarily reserved and allocated:
options: through which other traffic may be allowed to transit in VMC only
through which other traffic is not allowed to transit with out proper equipment
through which other traffic may be allowed to transit under ATC clearance

questions.question_text: MFA published in AIP ensures at least 1000 feet vertical clearance from obstacles within of center line?
options: 10 Kms
10 NMs
20 NMs

questions.question_text: Class C airspaces in India extend from to
options: Ground level, FL 150
4000 feet, FL 285
